CatDescriptText: Boisey Smith, steelworker, Fifth Ward and Emilene Hayes, teacher, Schenely [sic] Heights, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up series published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, May 20, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think that Negroes today, in Pittsburgh, are prone to follow Negro leadership in politics or do they consider it ineffective?  What do you think about their attitude nationally?"  Boisey Smith's answer reads: "I believe we do, both on the local and national levels."  Emilene Hayes' answer reads: "I believe our leadership is adequate.  However, the general Negro public is not informed as to what they are doing.  For instance, there's the situation in the 13th Ward which should be clarified so one could know just what is going on...If there was more information about Negro leaders, I think the following would be greater..."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Boisey Smith wearing flecked suit jacket and hat, standing on Wood Street with Raab Clothes and Dimlings Candy in background, Downtown; Portrait of Emilene Hayes wearing houndstooth coat, standing in front of Fanny Farmer candies, Wood Street, Downtown
